abstract.para: This topic covers how to find, search and interpret &selnx; denial messages.

topic.para: When &selnx; blocks an action, it generates a detailed log message. Understanding these logs is very important for troubleshooting and auditing the system's security with &selnx;.
The primary service responsible for handling &selnx; logs is the audit daemon, auditd. On a standard system, this service is enabled by default.

listitem.para: With auditd running (default): All &selnx; log messages are written to /var/log/audit/audit.log.
Without auditd running: If the auditd service fails or is not running, &selnx; log messages can be found instead in the systemd journal as a fallback.

topic.para: The most common log messages that are created by &selnx; are Access Vector Cache (AVC) denials, which record that a process was denied permission to access an object.

An AVC denial is a symptom, not the problem itself, so it is important to understand why the denial occurred. When initially setting up a workload or on upgrade scenarios, &selnx; blocking actions can be easily fixed by using the tools mentioned in . In contrast, AVCs occurring at later stages when the workload is running for while, might indicate a blocked intrusion attempt.
